entry.title: Combined summary - PSBT Addition (BIP 174) for authenticating source/output PSBT files
entry.summary: The Bitcoin-dev mailing list recently discussed the proposal to add signatures to Partially Signed Bitcoin Transactions (PSBTs) as a means of mitigating some broad "bug-classes." The discussion focused on whether authentication should be done with data embedded in the PSBT itself or with a container that includes PSBT and the authentication information. Some participants argued that adding extra fields would increase complexity and that MiTM protection should be done with out-of-band communication. Others proposed placing the signatures in a separate container.One proposal suggests verifying signatures on a digest of the PSBT file up to the last X bytes, ensuring that only the signature follows it. Another proposal suggests using pre-shared public keys between the PSBT Creator and Signer to mitigate the issue of a MiTM who can modify both directions of the PSBT. However, some participants argue that adding extra fields to PSBT would increase complexity and suggest verifying the signatures of each participant instead.Despite concerns about adding complexity and increasing the chance of bugs, the author plans to get two officially-assigned BIP-174 key numbers and add the feature to Coldcard's firmware, as well as write a BIP or make an addition to BIP-174. There were suggestions to implement the proposed scheme with proprietary keys, document it, and promote it, which could lead to it becoming a de-facto standard with non-proprietary keys assigned. Participants agreed that verification of these signatures is crucial.Discussions also revolved around whether participants should work from the same PSBT file if they all receive the same PSBT, or if they should work in a chain where the next participant receives updated PSBT from the previous participant. There were concerns about introducing additional ordering or other structural requirements over a simple key-value structure, which would add complexity to PSBT processing.Lastly, some suggested doing the protection via out-of-band communication such as PGP signing the PSBT or sending the signature separately. Overall, there are different perspectives on whether to add signatures to PSBT for MiTM protection, and participants acknowledge the importance of verifying any signatures added to PSBT. Support for PSBT signing and verification would need to be updated to support these new signatures.
